questions.question: This question requires that you evaluate the underlined text to determine if it is correct. You have a Power Apps app. You create a new version of the app and then publish the new version. A customer goes through the process of restoring the previous version of the app. In the Version tab for the app, you will see two versions of the app. Review the underlined text. If it makes the statement correct, select `No change is needed.` If the statement is incorrect, select the answer choice that makes the statement correct.
questions.explanation:
The underlined text stating "two versions of the app" will be visible is incorrect. When you create a new
version of a Power Apps app and subsequently publish it, each save and publish action creates a new version.
The Version tab within the Power Apps maker portal displays a history of all published versions of the
application. Restoring a previous version doesn't erase the subsequent versions; it simply sets the app back to
that specific point in its development. Therefore, if you have the original version, a new version is created and
published, and then you restore the original version, you will have at least the original version, the new version,
and then the restored version, which effectively counts as a third historical point. The Versions tab keeps a
record of each significant change, including when the app was published or restored to a previous state. This
provides a comprehensive audit trail, allowing developers to easily revert to any prior iteration if needed. So,
the correct number of versions visible would be three: the initial version, the updated version, and the version
after the restoration process.
Justification for Answer Choice C (three):
Answer choice C corrects the original statement by stating that three versions of the app would be visible in
the Version tab. This aligns with the way Power Apps manages version history. Each publish action, including a
restore, creates a new entry in the version history. Therefore, the original version, the updated version, and the
restored version will all be listed.
Authoritative Links for Further Research:
Power Apps Version Management: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-apps/maker/canvas-
apps/restore-an-app
Understand Power Apps app lifecycle: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/alm/basics-alm

questions.question: A company uses Dynamics 365 Sales. The company uses a browser-based app named Sales Hub. You need to ensure that users can access data from mobile devices. Which app should users install?
questions.explanation:
The correct app for users to install to access Dynamics 365 Sales data on mobile devices is Dynamics 365 for
Phones. The problem specifies that the company is using Dynamics 365 Sales and accessing it through the
browser-based Sales Hub application. Dynamics 365 for Phones is explicitly designed to provide a mobile
experience for Dynamics 365 applications, including Sales.
Options A, B, and C are incorrect because they represent different Dynamics 365 applications or add-ons that
do not directly fulfill the stated requirement of accessing Sales Hub data on mobile devices. Dynamics 365
Remote Assist focuses on mixed reality scenarios for remote collaboration. Dynamics 365 Finance and
Business Central are distinct ERP systems, not mobile clients for Dynamics 365 Sales.
Dynamics 365 for Phones (or the Dynamics 365 mobile app, as it is now generally referred to) provides
optimized access to Dynamics 365 data, including Sales, from smartphones and tablets. This allows users to
manage leads, opportunities, contacts, and other sales-related information while on the go. The app typically
syncs data with the main Dynamics 365 Sales instance, ensuring data consistency.
The app offers features tailored for mobile use, such as offline capabilities, camera integration for capturing
photos, and location services. It provides a consistent user experience, reflecting customizations and
configurations applied to the Sales Hub.
Authoritative links for further research:
Dynamics 365 App for Outlook User Guide: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/outlook-
app/overview
Dynamics 365 for phones and tablets User's Guide: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-
us/dynamics365/mobile/user-guide-phone-tablets

questions.question: You are a customer service manager. You need to implement a Power Apps portal that allows customers to submit cases. Which type of data source is used?
questions.explanation:
Here's a detailed justification for why Common Data Service (now Dataverse) is the most suitable data source
for a Power Apps portal designed for customer case submission, compared to the other options:
The core requirement is to store and manage customer case data. Dataverse (formerly Common Data Service)
is a cloud-based data platform specifically designed for building business applications, including those
centered around customer service. It offers a robust, secure, and scalable environment to store structured
data, with built-in features for relationships, business rules, workflows, and security. For customer service
scenarios, Dataverse provides pre-built entities (tables) like "Case" (or "Incident"), "Account," and "Contact,"
which significantly accelerates development.
The Dynamics 365 Connector (option A) can connect to Dynamics 365 Customer Service, which itself utilizes
Dataverse as its underlying data storage. However, selecting the Dynamics 365 Connector directly might
imply you are already deeply invested in and using the full Dynamics 365 suite. While feasible, choosing
Dataverse offers greater flexibility, especially if you only need the case management functionality without
other Dynamics 365 modules.
Microsoft SharePoint (option B) is primarily a document management and collaboration platform. While you
could store case information in SharePoint lists, it lacks the relational database capabilities and advanced
features of Dataverse needed for efficient case management (e.g., tracking relationships between cases and
customers, assigning priorities, managing SLAs). SharePoint is not optimized for structured data storage and
transactional operations required for a robust case management system.
Microsoft Azure Storage (option C) offers various storage services like Blob storage, Queue storage, and
Table storage. While highly scalable and cost-effective for unstructured data (like documents), it lacks the
structured data management capabilities, business rules, and security features provided by Dataverse. Using
Azure Storage directly would require significantly more custom development to build the necessary case
management functionality, including data validation, relationships, and security. It's more suited for storing
associated files or logs rather than the primary case data.
Dataverse provides the necessary structure, security, and scalability to support a customer case submission
portal, along with pre-built entities that are directly relevant to the scenario. This makes it the most efficient
and logical choice.
Authoritative links for further research:
1. Microsoft Dataverse: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/dataverse/
2. Power Apps Portals and Dataverse: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-
apps/maker/portals/data-platform-considerations
3. Dynamics 365 Customer Service: https://dynamics.microsoft.com/en-us/customer-
service/capabilities/

questions.question: A distribution company has multiple warehouses. Tax rates charged on sales orders need to be calculated based on locality and region. You need to recommend a cost-effective solution that can be implemented quickly. What should you recommend?

options.text: Check AppSource for a tax add-on.
Create alerts in Dynamics 365 Finance for tax table changes.
Write scripts and code tax updates.

questions.explanation:
The correct answer is A. Check AppSource for a tax add-on.
Here's why:
The scenario describes a need for dynamic tax calculation based on location for sales orders, a common
requirement for businesses. The key factors are cost-effectiveness and speed of implementation.
AppSource Add-on: Checking AppSource is the most practical first step. AppSource is Microsoft's
marketplace for apps and solutions that extend the functionality of Power Platform and Dynamics 365
applications. A pre-built tax add-on is likely to already handle location-based tax calculations, saving
significant development time and costs. This aligns with the cost-effective and rapid implementation criteria.
Let's examine why the other options are less suitable:
B. Create alerts in Dynamics 365 Finance for tax table changes: While alerts are useful for monitoring, they
don't address the core need of automated tax calculation on sales orders. They merely notify of changes, not
perform the calculation. If the company is using Dynamics 365 Finance, it could be part of a better solution
along with AppSource Add-on that supports D365.
C. Implement the Common Data Model: The Common Data Model (CDM) is a standardized data schema for
business entities. While useful for data integration, it doesn't directly solve the tax calculation problem. CDM
facilitates data sharing but does not provide a calculation engine. It is not directly related to the tax
calculation, making it less suitable as a solution.
D. Run a Power BI report: Power BI is a business intelligence tool for data analysis and visualization. It cannot
perform real-time calculations within a sales order. Power BI is for reporting on data, not real-time
transactional calculations. Power BI can be use for reporting on taxes collected, but not to calculate the tax.
E. Write scripts and code tax updates: This is the least cost-effective and slowest option. Developing custom
code requires significant time, expertise, and ongoing maintenance. This contradicts the requirements of
cost-effectiveness and rapid implementation. Custom development is more expensive and introduces more
potential points of failure.
Therefore, exploring pre-built tax add-ons from AppSource is the most efficient and cost-effective way to
address the company's requirements for location-based tax calculations.
Authoritative Links:
Microsoft AppSource: https://appsource.microsoft.com/
Dynamics 365 Finance: https://dynamics.microsoft.com/en-us/finance/overview/

questions.question: You need to implement Microsoft Business Applications along with the Microsoft Power platform. Which three Microsoft products are part of the Power platform? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
questions.explanation:
The answer provided, ACE (Power Apps, Power Automate, and Power BI), is the correct selection for the
Microsoft products that are core components of the Power Platform. The Power Platform is designed to
enable users to analyze data, automate processes, and build applications.
Power Apps: Enables users to build custom business applications with a low-code/no-code approach. It allows
for rapid development and deployment of apps that can run on various devices. These applications can
connect to different data sources. (https://powerapps.microsoft.com/en-us/)
Power Automate: Facilitates workflow automation between applications and services. It allows users to
automate repetitive tasks, improve productivity, and streamline business processes through automated
workflows. (https://powerautomate.microsoft.com/en-us/)
Power BI: Provides business intelligence and data visualization capabilities. It enables users to analyze data,
create interactive dashboards, and share insights across the organization. (https://powerbi.microsoft.com/en-
us/)
Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is a cloud-based identity and access management service, a core part of
Microsoft Azure, but not a core element of the Power Platform itself. While Power Platform services can
integrate with Azure AD for authentication and authorization, it is not a foundational building block of the
Power Platform in the same way the Power Apps, Automate, and BI are. Similarly, Azure Machine Learning is a
separate Azure service that provides tools and services for building and deploying machine learning models.
While it can be integrated with Power Platform applications, it is not a fundamental component of the
platform itself. The Power Platform focuses on low-code/no-code solutions for business users, leveraging
data analysis, app development, and process automation to enhance organizational efficiency.

questions.question: A large retail company implements Power Apps, Microsoft Flow, and the Common Data Service. The board of directors is asking whether users are finding value in the technology. The company would like to measure and report usage of the software. You need to recommend a tool to determine software usage. What should you recommend?
questions.explanation:
The correct answer is C, Power Platform Analytics. Here's why:
Power Platform Analytics is specifically designed to provide insights into the usage and performance of
Power Apps, Power Automate (formerly Microsoft Flow), and Power Virtual Agents. It's the go-to tool for
understanding how users are interacting with the Power Platform components within an organization. It
provides detailed reports and dashboards on app usage, flow runs, connector usage, and other key metrics.
Option A, Microsoft Intune, is a mobile device management (MDM) and mobile application management (MAM)
solution. While Intune can manage the Power Apps mobile app, it primarily focuses on device and application
security and compliance, not on detailed usage analytics within the Power Platform services themselves.
Option B, Azure Stream Analytics, is a real-time analytics service designed for processing large streams of
data. While Stream Analytics could theoretically be configured to ingest Power Platform telemetry data, it
requires significant custom configuration and development, making it an inefficient solution compared to the
out-of-the-box capabilities of Power Platform Analytics. Stream analytics is an overkill for the board's stated
need of general user adoption measurement for the Power Platform.
Option D, Dynamics 365 Product Insights, is focused on analyzing product usage and customer behavior
within Dynamics 365 applications. It doesn't directly provide insights into Power Apps and Power Automate
usage.
Power Platform Analytics is purpose-built for this scenario. It provides the features needed to understand how
users are adopting and utilizing the Power Platform, enabling the company to measure the value derived from
the technology, as requested by the board of directors.

Use Power BI to analyze your data:

questions.question: A company uses Power Platform. You must ensure that users cannot share customer data with other users. You must also ensure that uses cannot connect to data sources unless you grant the user explicit permissions to access a data source. You need to recommend solutions to meet the company's security requirements. Which two types of policies should you recommend? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
questions.explanation:
The requirement to prevent users from sharing customer data and restrict access to data sources unless
explicitly granted points to the need for policies that control data access and sharing at both a broad (tenant)
and specific (environment) level within the Power Platform.
Tenant-level policies (Option D), specifically data loss prevention (DLP) policies, are crucial for preventing
users from sharing sensitive data, like customer data, outside of approved channels or with unauthorized
users. These policies can be configured to block the sharing of data between certain connectors or
environments, effectively limiting the spread of sensitive information. DLP policies are defined at the tenant
level and apply across all environments within that tenant, providing a consistent baseline for data protection.
Environment-level policies (Option C), such as security groups and role-based access control (RBAC), are
essential for controlling access to data sources within specific environments. By assigning specific roles and
permissions to users within an environment, you can restrict access to data sources to only those users who
have a legitimate business need. This ensures that users cannot connect to data sources without explicit
permission. Environment-level policies allow for fine-grained control over data access, enabling you to tailor
security measures to the specific needs of each environment. Security roles determine what actions users can
perform.
Office cloud policies (Option A) are related to the configuration of Office 365 applications and services, but
don't directly address data sharing prevention or restricted data source access within Power Platform. Group
Policy Objects (Option B) are used for managing Windows environments and are not applicable to Power
Platform's cloud-based security features. Preset security policies (Option E) might exist, but the requirement
specifically calls for preventing data sharing and restricting data source access, which requires configuring
DLP policies and environment-level access controls rather than simply applying a pre-configured set of rules.
Therefore, they lack the granularity needed to meet the specific requirements of the question.
In summary, tenant-level DLP policies prevent data sharing, and environment-level policies control access to
data sources.
Relevant links for further research:
Power Platform DLP Policies: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/admin/wp-data-loss-
prevention
Power Platform Security Roles: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/admin/security-roles-
privileges

questions.question: A company is creating a canvas app to track and analyze customer visits to their retail stores. Data about customer visits is stored on-premises at each retail store location. The app must display data about customer visits when users launch the app. You need to ensure that the data is available for consumption by the app. Which tool should you use?
questions.explanation:
The correct answer is E. Data gateway.
Here's why: The scenario involves accessing on-premises data (customer visit data stored at each retail store)
from a cloud-based canvas app (built using Power Platform). To bridge this gap between the cloud and on-
premises environment, a data gateway is essential.
Data gateways act as a secure bridge, enabling cloud services like Power Apps, Power BI, Power Automate,
and Azure Logic Apps to connect to data sources located within a private on-premises network. They transfer
data between on-premises data sources and cloud services, maintaining data security and integrity.
Connectors facilitate connections to various data sources but don't inherently handle the complexity of
accessing data behind a firewall in an on-premises environment. They are used after the gateway has
established the initial secure connection.
Microsoft Dataverse is a cloud-based data platform, suitable for storing data natively in the cloud. However,
the scenario states that the data is already on-premises. Migrating the on-premises data to Dataverse would
require a separate process and might not be the desired approach.
Data source is a general term for where the data resides (e.g., a SQL Server database). It doesn't provide the
mechanism to access that data from the cloud when it's on-premises.
Power Automate can use a data gateway to access on-premises data for workflows, but in this context, the
primary need is to make the data accessible to the canvas app. Power Automate is a workflow automation tool
and not the core component for enabling cloud-based apps to access on-premises data.
Therefore, a data gateway provides the secure and necessary path for the canvas app to access the on-
premises data sources. It avoids migrating the data to the cloud and allows the app to consume the data
directly from its existing location.
Further reading on data gateways:
What are on-premises data gateways? | Microsoft Learn
Use data gateways in Power Platform dataflows - Power Query | Microsoft Learn

questions.question: A company currently does not separate testing, development and production as per standard Application Lifecycle Management (ALM) protocol. The company uses Power Apps for accounting and sales processes. The company needs to use only one login account per user. The company also must prevent development and testing from impacting production. You need to implement a solution to meet the requirements. Which method should you select?
questions.explanation:
The correct answer is A. Separate Environments.
Separating environments is the standard practice for Application Lifecycle Management (ALM) in Power
Platform. This approach directly addresses the company's requirements by isolating development and testing
activities from the production environment. This isolation prevents accidental changes or bugs introduced
during development and testing from affecting the live accounting and sales processes, crucial for business
continuity. By creating separate environments for development, testing, and production, the company can
follow a controlled release process, ensuring that only thoroughly tested and validated solutions are
deployed to production.
Using separate tenants (option B) is overkill and adds unnecessary complexity for a company with basic ALM
needs. Tenants are designed for complete isolation, often used when dealing with distinct organizations or
security requirements. Separate Azure Storage Blobs (option C) and Connectors (option D) are related to data
storage and integration, respectively, but do not address the core need to isolate development and testing
from production. These methods do not provide an independent and complete application development and
deployment lifecycle.
Separate environments within the same tenant allow the company to utilize the same user login accounts (as
the users remain within the same Azure Active Directory), satisfying the single login requirement. Dataverse
environments provide a clear distinction and control over data access and manipulation in each environment,
vital for security and compliance. They enable structured development, rigorous testing, and a safe
deployment process.
Resources:
Power Platform Environments Overview: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-
platform/admin/environments-overview
ALM with Power Platform: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/alm/overview-alm

questions.question: A company is evaluating ways that they can implement AI Builder. For which two scenarios can you use AI Builder? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.

options.text: Send emails to all users who subscribe to a service.
Synchronize data from an external database.
Collect data from several data sources and display a dashboard that shows trending data.
Interpret images and perform an action based on the image.
Detect patterns in data and predict outcomes.

questions.explanation:
AI Builder is a Microsoft Power Platform capability that enables businesses to easily add AI capabilities to
their workflows and applications without needing extensive coding or data science expertise.
D. Interpret images and perform an action based on the image: This is a core function of AI Builder. AI Builder
provides prebuilt AI models, such as object detection, which can be used to analyze images and trigger
actions based on what's recognized. For example, it could identify specific products in an image and
automatically update inventory levels or route invoices based on identified information.
E. Detect patterns in data and predict outcomes: AI Builder includes prediction models that can analyze
historical data to identify patterns and forecast future outcomes. This can be used for various purposes, like
predicting sales, identifying potential customer churn, or forecasting resource needs.
Options A, B, and C are not directly related to AI Builder's capabilities. Option A involves email marketing
functionality; option B deals with data integration which is related to Power Automate's connector
functionality and Power BI gateway; and option C is more aligned with Power BI's data visualization and
reporting capabilities.
Justification Summary: AI Builder focuses on image interpretation (object detection, form processing) and
predictive analysis based on data patterns, which directly supports options D and E.
Authoritative Links:
Microsoft AI Builder Documentation: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/ai-builder/
AI Builder Models Overview: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/ai-builder/prebuilt-models

questions.question: A company plans to use AI Builder to help improve business performance. You need to determine which AI Models are available for use. Which three types of models can you use? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
questions.explanation:
The correct answer is B, C, and E. Here's why:
Microsoft AI Builder provides prebuilt and custom AI models for various business needs within the Power
Platform. The available models include:
Prediction: This AI model type is used to forecast future outcomes based on historical data. For example,
predicting sales, delivery times, or customer churn.
Object Detection: This AI model identifies and counts specific objects within images or videos. Examples
include identifying products on a shelf, counting vehicles in a parking lot, or recognizing equipment on a
factory floor.
Text Classification: This AI model automatically categorizes text into predefined categories. Examples
include sentiment analysis of customer feedback, topic classification of news articles, or spam detection.
Why the other options are incorrect:
A. Linear Regression: While linear regression is a statistical method used in some forms of prediction, it's not
exposed as a direct, standalone "AI model" within AI Builder's prebuilt options. More complex predictive
models are used behind the scenes.
D. Anomaly Detection: While anomaly detection is an important AI capability, it is not natively available as a
directly usable "model" type within AI Builder. Instead, the necessary logic and models would need to be
developed by custom code.
In summary, AI Builder emphasizes ease of use by offering specific, task-oriented prebuilt models like
Prediction, Object Detection, and Text Classification.
For further information, you can consult the official Microsoft documentation:
AI Builder Overview: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/ai-builder/
AI Builder Models: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/ai-builder/prebuilt-models

questions.question: A company uses Microsoft 365 and Dynamics 365 Sales. The company does not have any developers on its staff. You need to explain to the executives the benefits of using Power Platform apps. What are two benefits? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.

options.text: Users can send emails from Dynamics 365 Sales to their personal email addresses.
Users can create Power Apps to create apps for different departments.
Users can use Power Automate to share information between Microsoft 365 and Dynamics 365 Sales.
The company can unify all the mobile devices to one vendor.

questions.explanation:
Here's a detailed justification for why options B and C are the correct benefits of using Power Platform apps in
the given scenario:
Option B: Users can create Power Apps to create apps for different departments.
Justification: Power Apps' low-code/no-code nature empowers business users (citizen developers) without
formal development skills to build custom applications. These applications can be tailored to specific
departmental needs within the company. Given the company lacks dedicated developers, this democratization
of app creation is a significant benefit. For example, the sales team can create an app to track leads, the
marketing team can build an app for managing campaigns, and HR can develop an app for employee
onboarding.
Cloud Computing Concept: Power Apps exemplifies Platform as a Service (PaaS), providing a managed
environment where users can build and deploy applications without managing the underlying infrastructure.
The visual interface and pre-built connectors simplify the development process.
Authoritative Link: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/power-apps/
Option C: Users can use Power Automate to share information between Microsoft 365 and Dynamics 365
Sales.
Justification: Power Automate allows users to automate workflows between different applications and
services. In this context, it enables seamless data exchange between Microsoft 365 (e.g., SharePoint,
Outlook) and Dynamics 365 Sales. For example, a lead created in Dynamics 365 Sales can automatically
trigger a new task in Microsoft Planner or send a welcome email from Outlook. Automation reduces manual
data entry, improves efficiency, and ensures data consistency across platforms.
Cloud Computing Concept: Power Automate demonstrates Integration Platform as a Service (iPaaS),
connecting disparate applications and services using pre-built connectors and workflow automation tools.
This eliminates the need for custom coding to integrate different systems.
Authoritative Link: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/power-automate/
Why the other options are incorrect:
Option A: Sending emails to personal email addresses directly from Dynamics 365 Sales doesn't showcase a
benefit of the Power Platform. This is a standard functionality of Dynamics 365 Sales and not specific to
Power Platform capabilities. Furthermore, depending on company policy, this could violate data privacy
regulations.
Option D: Unifying all mobile devices under one vendor isn't directly related to Power Platform's benefits.
Device management is a separate concern, typically addressed by Mobile Device Management (MDM)
solutions. Power Platform apps can be accessed on various devices, but they don't inherently enforce a single
device vendor.

questions.question: A company uses Dynamics 365 Supply Chain Management and Dynamics 365 Finance. User account data must be synchronized between the two systems. You need to ensure that the synchronized data is stored in one place. What should you use?
questions.explanation:
The correct answer is D, Microsoft Dataverse. Here's why:
Microsoft Dataverse is designed to be a unified data store and platform for Dynamics 365 applications and
Power Platform solutions. Given the requirement to synchronize user account data between Dynamics 365
Supply Chain Management and Dynamics 365 Finance and store it in one place, Dataverse is the ideal
solution.
Dataverse provides a common data model and business logic layer, allowing data to be easily shared and
managed across different applications. By using Dataverse, the company can avoid creating separate data
silos and ensure data consistency. Azure Active Directory (Azure AD), while managing user identities, doesn't
primarily serve as a central data repository for application data. SQL Server could store the data, but it would
require custom integration efforts and would not provide the built-in capabilities for Dynamics 365 and Power
Platform integration that Dataverse offers. Azure IoT Central is for IoT device management and data, not user
account synchronization between business applications. Dataverse streamlines data synchronization by
offering built-in connectors and integration capabilities with Dynamics 365 applications, making it the most
efficient and effective solution. Utilizing Dataverse promotes a more cohesive and integrated data
management strategy, which is essential for applications within the Dynamics 365 ecosystem and the Power
Platform.

Microsoft Dataverse Documentation: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/dataverse/
Integrate Dataverse with Dynamics 365: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/admin/connect-
apps-data-sources

questions.question: What is a benefit of deploying Microsoft 365 and Dynamics 365 apps in the same tenant?

options.text: Use Common Data Services to connect to application data.
You only need to set up groups in Microsoft 365 for permissions to all data.
Users can access both Microsoft 365 and Dynamics 365 by using Single Sign-on (SSO).

questions.explanation:
The correct answer is C. Users can access both Microsoft 365 and Dynamics 365 by using Single Sign-on
(SSO).
When Microsoft 365 and Dynamics 365 applications reside within the same tenant, users benefit from a
streamlined authentication experience through Single Sign-On (SSO). This means a user logs in once with
their Microsoft 365 credentials and is automatically authenticated for Dynamics 365 applications within the
same tenant. This eliminates the need to remember and enter multiple usernames and passwords, improving
user productivity and reducing IT helpdesk requests related to password management.
A single tenant simplifies user and security management for administrators. Because both application suites
share the same Azure Active Directory (Azure AD), administrators can manage user accounts, permissions,
and security policies centrally. This consolidates identity management, reducing complexity and improving
overall security posture.
While option A mentions Common Data Service (now Dataverse), its function is not solely dependent on both
services being in the same tenant, although it is greatly facilitated. Dataverse can be accessed regardless, but
integration is easier within the same tenant. Option B is an oversimplification. While a shared tenant simplifies
permissions, Microsoft 365 groups are not the only mechanism for managing access to all data across both
platforms. Dynamics 365 utilizes role-based security which requires dedicated setup. SSO specifically relates
to ease of user authentication across the two platforms.
For further reading, refer to Microsoft's documentation on Azure Active Directory and Single Sign-On:
What is Azure Active Directory?
Single sign-on to applications in Azure Active Directory

questions.question: A company is building apps to support their business operations. The apps will use connectors to access data from several data sources and respond to a number of events generated by components. Which two operations can you use for connectors? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
questions.explanation:
The correct answer is AD: Actions and Triggers. Here's why:
Actions: Connectors in Power Platform provide specific actions that can be performed on the connected data
source. These actions define the operations you can execute, such as creating a record, updating a field,
deleting an item, or retrieving data. Actions are initiated on demand, often as a part of a Power Automate flow
or Power Apps function call.
Triggers: Connectors also define triggers, which are events that cause a flow to start. These triggers monitor
a data source for a specific event, like a new email arriving, a file being modified, or a record being created.
When the trigger condition is met, the flow is automatically initiated.
Plug-ins: While plug-ins exist within the Power Platform ecosystem, particularly for Dataverse, they are
distinct from connectors. Plug-ins are custom code that executes on the Dataverse server-side in response to
data events. They extend the functionality of Dataverse directly.
Gateways: Gateways are used to connect to on-premises data sources from cloud-based Power Platform
services. They facilitate secure communication between the Power Platform environment and data located
within a private network. While essential for many scenarios, they are not operations that you can directly use
for connectors. They enable connectors to access on-premises data.
In essence, actions define what you do with a connector, while triggers define when something happens
because of the connector.
Further Research:
Power Platform Connectors Overview: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/connectors/
Triggers and Actions in Power Automate: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-automate/getting-started
Dataverse Plug-ins: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-apps/developer/data-platform/plug-ins
On-premises Data Gateway: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/data-integration/gateway/service-gateway-
onprem

questions.question: You are a sales manager for a large retail organization. You are creating a Power Apps app that will display customer product purchase information from your old point- of-sale (POS) system and need to link those sales to the customer accounts and product sales in Dynamics 365 Commerce. You need to use the appropriate component. What should you use?
questions.explanation:
The correct answer is A, Microsoft Dataverse. Here's why:
Dataverse is Microsoft's cloud-based data platform that allows you to securely store and manage data used
by business applications. In this scenario, you need a central repository to integrate data from your old POS
system with Dynamics 365 Commerce. Dataverse provides a unified data model, making it ideal for
connecting data from disparate sources.
Here's a breakdown of why the other options are less suitable:
Business Process Flow: Business process flows guide users through a series of steps to complete a process.
They don't handle data storage or integration.
Entity Metadata: Entity metadata describes the structure of entities (tables) within Dataverse, such as field
types and relationships. While important, it's not the component used for data integration itself.
Business Rule: Business rules automate actions based on certain conditions. They operate on data within an
entity but don't handle data integration from external systems.
Dataverse enables you to create entities to represent customers, products, and sales data. You can then use

questions.question: You create a Power Virtual Agents chatbot. You need to share the bot with other team members so that they can try out the bot before you share the bot with customers. What should you use?
questions.explanation:
The correct answer is A, demo website.
Here's why:
When developing a Power Virtual Agents chatbot, you need a way to test and refine it before public release.
Sharing the bot with internal team members for feedback is a crucial step. Power Virtual Agents provides a
"demo website" specifically for this purpose.
Demo Website Functionality: The demo website creates a unique URL that you can share with your team. This
URL allows them to interact with the chatbot within a web browser environment without affecting the live
production bot. The interface mimics the end-user experience, providing a realistic testing scenario. It allows
for isolated testing, so changes on the demo website don't impact the production version.
Why not a live production website?: A "live production website" is where the final, customer-facing version of
the bot resides. Using it for internal testing before wider release risks exposing unfinished or buggy versions
to actual users, leading to a poor user experience and potential reputational damage. This is why it's critical to
have a separate testing environment.
Why not the "test chat" feature alone?: While the "Test chat" pane within the Power Virtual Agents design
canvas is useful for individual testing and debugging, it doesn't readily facilitate sharing with a wider team for
collaborative feedback. The demo website offers a more accessible and shareable method.
Best Practice: Utilizing a demo website aligns with the best practices of software development and
continuous integration/continuous delivery (CI/CD). It allows for controlled testing, feedback gathering, and
iterative improvement before deploying the final product.
In summary, the demo website is the ideal solution because it creates a controlled, shareable environment
specifically designed for internal team testing of a Power Virtual Agents chatbot before its public launch. It
balances testing with a realistic environment without affecting end users.

questions.question: You create a Power BI dashboard that displays Common Data Model data. You need to share the Power BI dashboard with coworkers and allow the coworkers to collaborate. What are two possible ways to achieve the goal? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.

options.text: Create a Power BI workspace and grant coworkers permissions.
Publish the dashboard as an app to your coworkers.
Export the data to Microsoft Excel. Make required changes and then re-import the data.
Create a Power Automate flow to export the data into a SQL Server database.

questions.explanation:
The correct answer is AB. Here's why:
A. Create a Power BI workspace and grant coworkers permissions:
Power BI workspaces are collaborative environments specifically designed for sharing and working on Power
BI content, including dashboards, reports, and datasets.
By creating a workspace, you centralize the dashboard and its associated data in a secure and managed
location.
You can assign different roles (e.g., Admin, Member, Contributor, Viewer) to your coworkers, controlling their
level of access and the actions they can perform. This allows for collaboration while maintaining data
governance.
Workspaces enable features like shared datasets, allowing multiple reports and dashboards to be built upon
the same underlying data, promoting consistency and reducing redundancy.
B. Publish the dashboard as an app to your coworkers:
Power BI apps are curated collections of dashboards and reports packaged for distribution to a wider
audience.
Publishing an app provides a simplified and focused view of the dashboard, removing unnecessary navigation
elements and streamlining the user experience for consumers.
You can control who has access to the app by assigning permissions to individuals or groups, ensuring that
only authorized users can view the data.
Apps are useful for deploying dashboards to teams or departments where direct collaboration on the
dashboard's design is not required, but access to the insights is essential.
Why C and D are incorrect:
C. Export the data to Microsoft Excel. Make required changes and then re-import the data: This approach is
not collaborative in Power BI. It's more of a manual, individual process. It also introduces risks of data
inconsistency and errors if multiple people make changes to the Excel file separately. Re-importing the data
effectively breaks the link to the original Common Data Model data source, negating Power BI's data refresh
capabilities.
D. Create a Power Automate flow to export the data into a SQL Server database: While exporting data to
SQL Server can be useful in some scenarios for archiving or further analysis, it doesn't directly facilitate
collaboration within Power BI itself. It adds unnecessary complexity and creates a new data silo separate from
the Common Data Model data. This approach also doesn't provide the interactive dashboard experience that
Power BI is designed to offer.

tables based on the store number. The sales transactions table contains the store number within the
transaction ID, while another table stores the mapping between store number and store name.

allows you to extract the store number from the transaction ID in the sales transactions table using functions
like Text.Start or Text.Range. Once the store number is extracted, a relationship can be created between the
sales transactions table and the store information table, linking them through the store number field. This
relationship enables you to display the store name in reports based on the corresponding store number within
each transaction.

Excel (C) could be used for initial data manipulation, but is not integrated within Power BI's data loading and
transformation pipeline as effectively as Query Editor. A Data Connector (D) is used to initially pull data from a
source into Power BI, but doesn't provide the needed data transformations in this case. Query Editor directly
within Power BI Desktop is the ideal place to modify and model the data to establish the relationship needed
to show store names in sales reports.

questions.question: A company is building an interactive chatbot to answer questions about product and product warranties. You need to create conversation paths for questions about product warranties. Which tool should you use?
questions.explanation:
The question asks for the best tool to create conversation paths for a chatbot handling product warranty
inquiries. The proposed answer is "Authoring canvas." Let's analyze why this is potentially correct while also
considering alternative interpretations.
Option A, "Authoring canvas," likely refers to the visual design interface within Power Virtual Agents (PVA).
PVA is a low-code platform specifically designed for building chatbots. The authoring canvas allows users to
visually design the conversational flow, including defining triggers (like warranty-related questions),
responses, and conditional branching to guide the user through the interaction. It provides a graphical user
interface (GUI) that makes it easy to create and manage the chatbot's conversation paths. It allows for
dragging and dropping different conversation components, like questions, conditions, and actions, to create a
visual representation of the conversation flow.
Option D, "Power Virtual Agents portal," is also a strong contender because the Authoring Canvas is a part of
the Power Virtual Agents portal. The PVA portal provides the overarching environment for building, testing,
deploying, and managing chatbots. However, the specific task of designing conversation paths is most
directly performed on the Authoring Canvas.
Option B, "Azure Bot Framework," is a more developer-centric platform that requires coding skills and is
designed for creating more complex bots. While it's possible to use Azure Bot Framework, it would be overkill
for a simple chatbot answering product warranty questions. It's also outside of the scope of the Power
Platform Fundamentals exam.
Option C, "Power Platform admin center," is used for managing environments, data loss prevention policies,
and other administrative tasks, not for building chatbot conversations.
The subtle distinction is that the portal hosts the tools to build the bot, while the Authoring Canvas is the tool
itself used to build the paths.
Based on the wording of the question, focusing on creating conversation paths, the Authoring Canvas (A),
which is the visual tool within PVA for designing those paths, is the most accurate and direct answer.

appropriate solution for this scenario. Furthermore, Power Pages is explicitly designed for external user
access to Dataverse data in a secure and controlled manner.

The customer records are displayed in a list on a screen labeled Browse. You need to modify a property of the control on the screen. Which control should you modify?
questions.explanation:
The correct answer is D. Gallery. Here's why:
When you create a canvas app from data (like a spreadsheet), Power Apps automatically generates a basic
app with screens for browsing, viewing details, and creating/editing records. The screen labeled "Browse"
typically presents the customer records in a list format using a Gallery control. The Gallery control is
designed to display repeating items (in this case, customer records) from a data source.
You'd modify the Gallery control's properties to change how the list is displayed, such as:
Items: Specifies the data source (e.g., your spreadsheet).
TemplateFill: Changes the background color of each row.
Layout: Selects the arrangement of items within the Gallery (e.g., Title, subtitle, and body).
Individual controls within the gallery template (like labels for names or addresses)
Why other options are incorrect:
A. Display form: The Display form is used for showing the details of a single selected record, not for
displaying a list of records on the "Browse" screen.
B. Icon: Icons are graphic elements. While icons might be present within the Gallery for actions like "delete" or
"edit," modifying them doesn't change the overall display of the customer records list itself.
C. Search: The Search control is for filtering the data displayed in the gallery. It does not directly control the
presentation of individual records. The Gallery uses the search result returned by the search control.
In summary, the Gallery control is the core component responsible for displaying the list of customer records
on the "Browse" screen. Any modification to the appearance or content of this list necessitates adjusting the
properties of this control.
